fields.description:
I trusted that the "Check default remotes for updates every X minutes" would delete remote branches automatically. However, much to my surprise and my team, people were pushing up old deleted branches because they trusted the automatic refresh was pruning them locally.

I suggest that you add a checkbox in the Preferences to add the PRUNE option to the fetch (git fetch -p) so users can truly appreciate the automatic refresh and not have to worry about having to fetch -p manually.
fields.summary: Add user preference to include the PRUNE option in the automatic Remote status refresh

fields.description: The white background of the diff sheet is to wide, please see attached picture.
fields.summary: White diff sheet background is 1 pixel to wide

fields.description:
See attached screenshot; STASHES is collapsed and SUBMODULES is expanded but there's no way to know immediately that STASHES has children - it looks like an empty list.

To find out you have to mouse-over the label to have the 'Show' tooltip appear.
fields.summary: Left-sidebar sections have no differentiation between collapsed and empty

fields.description: It would be great to be able to do the equivalent of a hg commit --close-branch from within the GUI. In our development model, feature branches normally get closed after the feature has been merged into one of the main branches.
fields.summary: add a "close branch" command to the GUI

fields.description:
The old icons were easy to identify by shape and colour. The new icons are MUCH harder to distinguish as many are very similar shapes and size and all are now basically the same colour, which is also a very dark colour, and when there is a small amount of another colour on an icon it is also very dark.

I understand that this has been a trend in Apple's bundled apps for a few releases of OS X now, but it's really bad for usability.

What's wrong with the good old Human Interface Guidelines which call for the use of distinct colour AND shape in addition to text labels for toolbar buttons?
fields.summary: The new "enhanced" icons are a MASSIVE step backwards! Please revert!

fields.description:
When a branch has the same name as a tag, [it errors when pushing to origin|^screenshot1.png]. Steps to reproduce:
# Add a Git repository.
# Push to a remote.
# Create a branch (eg. stsp-420).
# Create a tag on master with the same name (eg. stsp-420).
# Push the created tag to the remote.
# Change to the created branch.
# Make a change and commit on the branch.
# Push the new commit from the branch.
fields.summary: Pushing Branch With the Same Name as a Tag Fails

fields.description:
I right-clicked on a file and chose "Blame Selected..."

The window that popped up had these columns:

* Line
* Author
* Changeset
* Content

I believe the first three columns are rendered with the default system font. The last column is rendered in the font I selected as my "Diff View Font."

That seems reasonable except that, due mostly to my fading eyesight, my diff display font is significantly larger than the default display font.

It appears that the text for the first three columns is "top-aligned" (rather than "center-aligned" or "bottom-aligned"). Between the smaller font and the odd alignment, the visual effect is very unhelpful. It's hard to track the correspondence between the first three columns and the last one.

I'm using 13-point "Oxygen Mono" for my diff content.
fields.summary: Font awkwardness in "blame" display

fields.description:
{panel:title=Oops!}
I never should have submitted this issue. I was using SourceTree on a rotated display, so I didn't see the "Path" column in the file list.

I would close this ticket myself, but I'm not authorized.  Sorry for occupying bytes on your hard drive.
{panel}

In the bottom-right part of the display, where SourceTree displays the details about a specific commit, there is a list of files that were changed for the current commit.

This list shows only the base file names. This is very sensible, since the full path to a given file can be arbitrarily long, and the result could be completely unhelpful.

However, I happen to be looking at a project with relatively short paths, and it would really help me understand the full context of a commit if I could see the full path of each file.

Just off the top of my head, I see two possible solutions:

# Give me a little check box in the corner of the file name list that toggles full paths on or off.
# Give me an alternate layout of the commit detail that "stacks" the metadata, file list, and diff display so that the file list can be as wide as possible. I find the current layout to be quite sensible, but I think the alternate layout may be better in some circumstances.
fields.summary: Optionally show full path names in commit detail

fields.description:
I would like to be able to show/hide the sidebar of SourceTree with a keyboard shortcut. At present, I can't assign a custom shortcut because the action doesn't appear on any menus of the application.

Ideally, I'd like the shortcut to be Ctrl + Option + Command + D, which would match my TextMate and SublimeText setups, but I'm happy as long as I can customise it.
fields.summary: Keyboard Shortcut for Show/Hide Sidebar

fields.description:
I'm a Mac user and Sourcetree is definitely my tool of choice to work with Git repositories. The user interface is "clean" and easy to use.
The release of the Windows version was great which I recommended to all my team mates :)

However the last update introduced a new set of icons that I think are less intuitive than previous versions, not to mention that they are ugly :P

I hope this feedback would be useful in some way to improve future versions of the product.

Best regards,
fields.summary: New set of icons

fields.description: As screenshot shows, this needs to be in 1.6
fields.summary: Hosting services should say "Bitbucket" not "BitBucket"

fields.description: Taken from STSP. It was reproducible there so no need to keep it there any longer as it affects everyone. Link here: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-379
fields.summary: Bookmarks sometimes do not refresh if you are using groups

fields.description: Support autocomplete for files, which are in current commit (look at TortoiseSVN on Windows to see how it works).
fields.summary: Support auto-complete for files in commit-message

fields.description:
You could essentially do a 'git log' (and hg equivalent) against a repo for the current rev and get a quick file listing and then determine the progress of clone by ticking them off a list, essentially. Although this means the clone will take longer you will get more accurate feedback.

Based on this AAC: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/146754/unable-to-clone-a-bitbucket-git-repo
fields.summary: Progress bar when cloning repo

fields.description:
Support auto-complete with JIRA (also On Demand).

Entering e.g. TEST- should show me (my) open tasks in "TEST"-project on JIRA.
fields.summary: Integrate with JIRA / Support auto-complete

fields.description: SourceTree suffers from degraded performance/slowness when dealing with large repositories.  This is true for both GIT, and Mercurial.
fields.summary: Performance issues with large repo's

fields.description:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/148223/show-last-heads

Ultimately we want to be able to show those commits that don't have branch pointers, this will need a new screen of some kind to show those before they get garbage collected. The commits are essentially 'lost' as the AAC entry states.
fields.summary: Show orphaned commits

fields.description:
Currently it is only possible to shelf and unshelf all files in the working directory.

Shelf and Unshelf operations should offer a dialog with a list of files to add or remove from the shelf.
fields.summary: Partial shelf and unshelf files

fields.description: It would be great not to close commit window after commit, if some not committed files left there. GitExtensions has such option, it's very useful
fields.summary: Option not to close commit window after commit

fields.description:
For the moment there are at least three places in the app where files lists can be found:
1 Working copy status
2 Changeset diff
3 Commit window

Visually they are almost the same, but in fact they behave differently. For example:
1 You can view diff by pressing Cmd+D in working copy status, but can't in other lists
2 You can call context menu (with right click) in working copy status and changeset diff, but can't in commit window

Commit window has the worst behavior: you can't do anything there you can in another places.

It's confusing and I waste lots of time, when closing commit window and going to working copy status to just revert the file

All file lists must behave equally
fields.summary: Files lists behavior

fields.description:
Problem: on github in our project a new tag was created by somebody else. It was not yet present in tags list in sourcetree. I tried fetch on branches and other ways in SourceTree but wouldn't appear. Only by commandline with 'git fetch -t' and reopening project I would get them.

Suggestion: add a manual way to refresh tags by adding a refresh/fetch option in context menu below tags menu option.
fields.summary: Add manual way to refresh tags

fields.description:
SourceTree supports custom Commit Text Replacements and we have a KB article from a while ago for how to set up Bitbucket issue liniks: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/SOURCETREEKB/Link+to+Bitbucket+issue+tracker+from+commits

See the comments, this doesn't appear to be working any more. I'm not sure if they mean the links are not showing, or that they link to the wrong place, but we should try to nail this asap.
fields.summary: Linking to Bitbucket issues in commit messages: KB approach no longer works

fields.description: The git flow docs are unavailable (click the '?' from the git flow initialise window). Requested via AAC here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/146287/git-flow-help-unavailable
fields.summary: Git flow docs unavailable

fields.description:
I think we should have the ability to enable/disable specific repo's from being refreshed. Some users have a big list but don't want git/hg to sit there going through all of them and refreshing as they don't care about many. Perhaps have some kind of 'last refreshed' text with some visual cue of a refresh that happened long ago.

This issue runs on the back of: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/146290/background-activity-indication-single-session-disable-option-bandwidth-management

We have had this requested in the past. I was certain an issue has been filed for it but I cannot find anything as of yet.
fields.summary: More granular control over repository refresh

fields.description: "Stage Selected Lines" or Hunks doesn't seem to do anything. Does this feature actually work? In the successful case, what is created as a result, what identifiable difference is there?
fields.summary: "Stage Selected Lines" doesn't seem to do anything

fields.description: Enhancements to the log view as requested here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/145328/is-it-possible-to-view-the-full-file-tree-for-a-given-commit
fields.summary: Full file-tree of repo at given commit without checking out

fields.description:
I usually work in the "log" view, reviewing pending changes in the "Uncommitted changes" log line.

When I want to view the entire project, e.g. to find a specific file and view its log or blame, I jump to the "file status" view. It almost always defaults to showing only "pending" files, though.

This is almost *never* what I actually want. I've just done some testing and SourceTree is very inconsistent in how and when it will remember the style and filter for the "file status" and "log" views.

Ideally what I want is "tree view" and "show all" in "file status", and "flat view" and "show pending" in "Uncommitted changes" in "log" view. And I want SourceTree to remember this.

It seems like I CAN set them separately, e.g. if both are set to "flat view" and "show pending", then I set "file status" view to "tree view" and "show all", I can switch back and forth between "file status" and "log" view no problem. But when I quit and re-open SourceTree, BOTH will be "tree view" (but "show XYZ" will be remembered).

If I then change "log" back to "flat view" and quit and re-open, then BOTH will be "flat view" AND "show pending".

This could be remembered per repository, or just for the whole app overall. Either way, I just want to avoid constantly resetting view and filter options :)
fields.summary: Remember filter options in "file status" view.

fields.description:
Currently SourceTree only lists repos user is following.
It should list all repos the user has access to.
fields.summary: SourceTree should list all repositories user has access to

fields.description: It would be really nice to be able to run a command on all repositories in one group. I have a large multi-repository project and when I change something in a lot of repositories and would like to push them at the same time I have to do it manually.
fields.summary: Push and pull all repositories in group

fields.description:
When starting a new hotfix via {{Repository > Git flow / Hg flow > Start New Hotfix}}, it asks for a hotfix version value.
[In the example|^screenshot1.png], a JIRA issue ID is used.
However, when finishing the hotfix, there is the option to tag the [resulting commit with a message|^screenshot2.png].
When confirming, that message is ignored and the hotfix version value [is shown duplicated instead|^screenshot3.png].
fields.summary: Git Flow / Hg Flow Hotfix Tagging is Broken

fields.description:
Originally discussed via Twitter here: https://twitter.com/chrisyipw/status/307402350333665280 

Technically this is correct behaviour in Git. When accepting a pull request from a forked branch, the branch is then closed which is correct. The problem is that the ref to the branch no longer exists, so pushing/pulling is just failing. We need some way of detecting whether the remote branch exists anymore and perhaps offer the option to the user to delete the branch and switch back to master?

I assume this has been raised before. The easy solution is to just switch branches and delete the old branch, but it'd be nice if on a pull it gets deleted for the user automatically and giving some nice message to say the pull request was accepted and the branch was closed. We could do some API integrations to make this work, need to take a look into it though.
fields.summary: Closed remote branches - detect and close

fields.description:
DELETE THIS :-).

Extremely embarrassing. Seconds after filing this, I discovered that there already *is* an option for making the commit field use a fixed space font. Sorry for the nice. Not sure how to delete this report..
fields.summary: Switch commit message input field to use a monospaced font

fields.description:
When sorting by file or path names in the working copy view, the sort is case sensitive. 

Not only is this inconsistent with how files are sorted in OSX Finder but, in my opinion, not natural for most humans to read. 

I don't know if it has been this way for a while or recently changed, but I would sure like it to be case insensitive.
fields.summary: On OSX, sorting of working copy view should be case insensitive

fields.description: Requested via Twitter here: https://twitter.com/jpfarias/status/306642205483884544
fields.summary: Pull + update from the bookmarks window for multiple projects simultaneously

fields.description:
If a tag moved and a client amends a remote tag then you need to force fetch your tags in order for the refspec in git to be overridden. You can only do this by git fetch --tags. From the docs:

"This is a short-hand for giving "refs/tags/:refs/tags/" refspec from the command line, to ask all tags to be fetched and stored locally. Because this acts as an explicit refspec, the default refspecs (configured with the remote.$name.fetch variable) are overridden and not used."

Reported on AAC: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/141421/sourcetree-pull-all-tags
fields.summary: --tags option to git fetch

fields.description:
I'm looking at files in my working copy, listed under the sub-pane entitled "Files in the working tree."

If I right-click on a file, I can choose "Log selected..." to view the history of changes to that file.

If I select a directory, "Log selected..." is grayed out.

From the command line, I _can_ view the log for a directory (which I believe is simply the union of logs for all subordinate files, and exactly what I want).

It's often the case that less functionality is available through a GUI than is available from the command line. I believe this function is important enough that it should be surfaced in the GUI.

It may be relevant that I have SourceTree set to use my installation of Git 1.8.1.3, which I downloaded from git-scm.org.
fields.summary: Can't get the change log for a directory

fields.description:
If changes are not pushed yet to the Git (or SVN), I am able to change the history without producing conflicts with others.

However, the process of rewriting is not so easy; it requires currently a switch to the terminal, path, git hacking, mostly-not-my-editor-of-choise and a strict usage of _git- rebase -i_ so I'm always searching for a good best practice, tutorial. This isn't a every day work task (well, because it is not so simple).

What about a clean, simple and small feature integration? 

I would suggest a small UI which allows to change only the commit messages of the last unpushed commits. A list with editable lines = commit messages. Easy.


In the future, however, the working progress could require more details, but this would be more internally work. I could imagine that squashing commits could be easily done (if they are side by side). Same to splitting a commit, this needs the diff-editor. 

But moving a commit (move a commit up or down) could require more checks, whether this is actually possible or not (and would require additional conflict merging).
fields.summary: Rewrite commit message history (no amend)

fields.description: The message isn't used when creating a lightweight tag so it should be disabled in the UI.
fields.summary: Selecting "Lightweight tag" should disable "Message" input

fields.description: Please consider adding the ability to select multiple remotes to push to when committing.
fields.summary: "Push commits immediately to:" Multiple remotes

fields.description:
I suspect that it's due to the retina display, but the path is shown in light gray and the font size is so tiny, that it's virtually impossible to read.

I'm attaching a screen shot, but note that this is displayed in a very small area on the screen (I'm using the 15" set to 1920x1080). The main project and branch names are fine. Just the font and color of directory folder.

-jcw
fields.summary: fonts in bookmark window are too small

fields.description:
While scrolling through the branch history view (using the mouse-wheel or two fingers) SourceTree will occasionally auto-refresh this list. When this happens the current scroll position is lost and reset to the selected line.

Since this refresh sometimes happens several times in a row it makes a very frustrating user experience and often there has not even been a change in the content of the list.

Possible improvements might be: 
1) Store, and then restore the scroll position when the list is refreshed
2) Prevent the list from refreshing several times in a row. Can these refreshes all happen but not refresh the UI until the last one is complete?
3) Don't perform an automatic refresh until a certain number of minutes has elapsed since the user last scrolled this list. (Or perhaps interacted with anything in the UI?)
fields.summary: Try to maintain scroll position in branch view when refreshing

fields.description: Cloning a repo displays the OSX "candy stripe" progress bar, which gives no indication of how much more you've got left. Commandline git is nice enough to provide % completed. Just sayin'.
fields.summary: Better download status during clone of large repo over not-so-fast connection

fields.description:
Using a 20 character password works:

bq. xj6xt88X7328b7f2Y7Q

But a 50 character password fails:

bq. jynaECD4uP8a6e2YVH6gKeCiNKDLrKfhe37mGUP7zFeAp3N7zX
fields.summary: BItBucket authentication fails if password has too many characters

fields.description:
It would be great to have the commit tree graph displayed in swim lanes, like the diagrams at http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/ .

I imagine it rotated 180 degrees. Master on the left, hot fixes, releases, develop and then feature branches.

The swim lane model has really helped my thinking about how to use git, and helps when Im explaining git to new users.
fields.summary: Option to display commit graph in swim lanes as per git-flow

fields.description:
Currently if you try to search for hg, mercurial, scm SourceTree is not going to appear in Spotlight (Cmd+Space or even on Launcher search).

If you add these keywords, and maybe others, to the Spotlight Comments (the OS stores them in .DS_Store and/or extended attributed people will be able to find the app correctly.

Please do not ignore this, as it may increase the usage of the app, if people are not able to find it in no-time, they will go for alternative.
fields.summary: Please add hg, mercurial, scm as spotlight comments for SourceTree.app

fields.description:
Raised from: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/56084/reverse-merge-in-source-tree?page=1#comment-138684

Currently reversing a merge commit will cause problems, both in git and hg.

Git has a 'revert' option '-m' which can be used to reverse merges correctly, see: http://git-scm.com/2010/03/02/undoing-merges.html

We should support that when a user selects a merge to reverse. We should also investigate whether there is an equivalent option for hg.
fields.summary: Handle reversing merge commits better

fields.description:
Raised from: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/56084/reverse-merge-in-source-tree?page=1#comment-138684

Currently reversing a merge commit will cause problems, both in git and hg.

Git has a 'revert' option '-m' which can be used to reverse merges correctly, see: http://git-scm.com/2010/03/02/undoing-merges.html

We should support that when a user selects a merge to reverse. We should also investigate whether there is an equivalent option for hg.
fields.summary: Handle reversing merge commits better

fields.description:
I find myself using the "Log" and "Blame" actions quite frequently at the moment and therefore - for shamelessly selfish reasons - would like to ask you to consider adding them to the available toolbar set please.

Thank you!
fields.summary: 'Log' and 'Blame' actions in the optional toolbar actions set

fields.description:
Hi all,

I tend to use multiple machines for development and I have SourceTree installed on all of them. I am also using the exact same layout for my Projects folder on all these machines. 

Currently I need to setup the groups/bookmarks manually on all my machines and this is slow and error-prone. So ideally I would like that these settings are somehow synchronised between machines (maybe using Dropbox?). Also it would be nice if SourceTree would automatically, on startup, check if I have all the bookmarks cloned on the current machine and if not, it should prompt me to clone the missing ones.

Thanks!

S.
fields.summary: Support for multi-machine usage

fields.description: Not been able to reproduce as of yet, but need to investigate further.
fields.summary: Repository list doesn't line up in table

fields.description:
Shortcuts are wonderful, and fortunately SourceTree has a lot of them. 
A table that lists all of them could be very very useful.
Why don't you add it to the documentation?
fields.summary: Document a table with all the shortcuts

fields.description:
I love the option "Do not fast forward when mergin, always create commit", but sometimes one needs to merge with a fast forward.
Unfortunately, afaik there's no way to select "use fast forward" or "do not fast forward" on a single merge basis, when selecting "merge" with the contextual menu.
The global option is still very useful, since it determines the default behavior. But an option for a single merge could be very useful
fields.summary: Ask "Do not fast forward?" a single merge basis

fields.description:
While committing, a new dialog is shown. This could be very large and hence cover the main windows.
Unfortunately, there's no reference to the current branch being used.
One must remember to which branch is committing. This isn't usually a problem, but since adding a label should be pretty trivial this could be a nice and cheap feature to have.
fields.summary: Add a reference to the current branch in the current dialog

fields.description:
In order to commit files one, they should be staged. SourceTree shows them in the "Files in the working tree" area.
Files must be drag&drop into the "Files staged in the index" area.
With a drag&drop files can be unstaged.

In order to speedup operations, 2 shortcuts could be introduced: one to stage one of more files, one to unstage them.

Using the mouse is really annoying. A developer could have an alternative.
fields.summary: Shortcuts in commit dialog to stage/unstage files

fields.description:
iTerm2 has a feature called "Hotkey window" which is a special Terminal window that slides in from the top of the screen upon pressing a special hotkey.

When I press the Terminal button in SourceTree, a new tab is created in this special window, although it is hidden, and an audible bell is played.

Expected behaviour would be to open a new "normal" iTerm2 window, although I don't know wether thats even possible from your side or a iTerm2 bug.
If you have no control over this, just close this bug ;)
fields.summary: Open Terminal creates new Tab in iTerm2 Hotkey window

fields.description: It'd be awesome if there were tabs or a sidebar menu where we could switch between active repos, instead of needing separate windows.
fields.summary: View Multiple Repositories in the Same Window

fields.description: In the search view allow filtering by branch also
fields.summary: Filter by branch in search pane

fields.description:
'git fetch --tags' retrieves orphaned tags from the remote (those which are not referenced by any branch). Most of the time people don't want them, since if you delete a remote branch you don't want to have to go through deleting every tag on that branch too, but occasionally someone does want to be able to grab the orphaned tags.

Add a checkbox to the Fetch dialog to enable retrieving of orphaned tags. The option should default to false.
fields.summary: Add an option to the Fetch dialog to add --tags parameter

fields.description: See screenshot.
fields.summary: Merge tool gets set twice in drop-down list

fields.description:
Can someone add a way to do a search or find a GIT change using the SHA?

There's been times I know a GIT change (SHA) and want to cherry-pick it to to the branch I'm currently on.

I can search by username - but that's too many results. I'd like to just do a Menu->Find and enter the change number.
fields.summary: Search/Find SHA in full history view

fields.description: It says 'Aborting rebase' rather than the Japanese translation. This may apply to French as well.
fields.summary: 'Aborting rebase' translation

fields.description: Reported via Twitter: https://twitter.com/ErikEvenson/status/301388352995852289
fields.summary: Delete branch hot key

fields.description: I suggest adding a menu item under the Custom actions menu saying "Edit custom actions..."  It's hard to find under prefernces when I'm looking for custom actions.  (Put it where my attention is.)  I would also remove the tab from preferences, but I'd understand if inertia compels you to keep it there.
fields.summary: Add Edit item to Custom Actions menu

fields.description: Reported by Dave via Twitter: https://twitter.com/doclaphroaig/status/301039579195121664
fields.summary: Offset progress panels when cloning more than one repo

fields.description:
When using a Git repo, users have the option of pulling with rebase. This is not the default behaviour; by default a pull will always create a merge commit. The merge commit is often unnecessary and a symptom of avoiding an "unsafe" rebase operation. However, the rebase is only "unsafe" if certain constraints can't be met, and these constraints can be checked programmatically.

I think there is opportunity to remove a needless choice and complexity from the end-user here, and avoid unnecessary git history clutter in the process.

There's an extension to Git's command-line tools called "[Git Smart|https://github.com/geelen/git-smart]". It implements what I would call the "safe and sensible" version of git pull: {quote} In brief, it'll detect the best way to grab the changes from the server and update your local branch, using a git rebase -p if there's no easier way. It'll also stash/pop local changes if need be.{quote} There's also a [full annotated code explanation|http://github-displayer.heroku.com/geelen/git-smart/raw/master/docs/smart-pull.html]. 

I think SourceTree would become a little more user-friendly were the "pull" operation to implement the functionality of Git-Smart. In doing so, you can:
* Remove one decision from the user on each pull operation
* Remove a configuration option to toggle the default behaviour (pull with rebase vs. merge)
* Avoid needless merge commits in the history.
fields.summary: Simplify the merge vs. rebase choice for novice users

fields.description: In SourceTree if a repository is renamed (in the example from ["mask"|^screenshot1.png] to ["The Mask"|^screenshot2.png]), when using Mac OS Exposé the reference is not updated. The same happens on the menu bar {{File > Open Recent}}.
fields.summary: SourceTree Does Not List Renamed Repositories in Exposé

fields.description:
As discussed via Twitter with Steven Fisher:

https://twitter.com/tewha/status/299575024057192448 
https://twitter.com/tewha/status/299575368237596672 

Basically replace the MGScopeBar with something 'nicer' that doesn't stand out so much.
fields.summary: Change the scope bar with newer Apple UI elements

fields.description: Reported via Twitter: https://twitter.com/DmitriyLikhten/status/299520946077835264
fields.summary: Move diff / commit panes around

fields.description:
i.e. when you click on a commit in the log view.

Reported via Twitter: https://twitter.com/MattSchweers/status/299555827906392064
fields.summary: Have horizontal panes (tree views etc.) for log view

fields.description:
In the File Status preview area there is the ["Discard" button at the top for the entire file and "Discard Hunk" button at the bottom of each hunk|^screenshot2.png]. When clicking in one of these buttons, a confirmation box is shown with ["Discard"|^screenshot3.png] used as the term.

However, when right-clicking on a file, there is no "Discard" menu. The equivalent is ["Reset"|^screenshot1.png] but when selecting this menu, a confirmation box is shown with ["Discard"|^screenshot4.png] used as term.

In the "Actions" menu, the relevant menu is named "Revert/Reset Selected..."

It would be better to use the same terminology for the same action.
fields.summary: Use Same Terminology For Similar Actions

fields.description: Like we can for adding/removing files, we should be able to turn of the confirmation dialog for deleting hunks. Thanks!
fields.summary: Please allow turning off confirm for hunk discarding

fields.description:
When using the search bar to search [through commit messages|^screenshot1.png], [SourceTree fails to find commits on remote branches|^screenshot2.png].

It would be nice to have SourceTree showing all commits reachable from all branches that match the search string.
fields.summary: Search on Remote Branches (use --all option to git log)

fields.description: Requested via Twitter here: https://twitter.com/joethephish/status/296991582543032320
fields.summary: Subtree: Detach sub-directory and retain version history

fields.description: It would be great of SourceTree would refresh the files in the working tree after a patch is applied so that you could see an up-to-date version of the working tree without having to manually refresh.
fields.summary: Refresh working tree after applying a patch

fields.description: Kaleidoscope (v2 at least) supports doing simultaneous diff of multiple files. Using git difftool shows all the changes in all files for a specific commit. It would be great if Sourcetree supported this as well with its External Diff button.
fields.summary: Support external diff of all files in commit (with Kaleidoscope)

fields.description: There's two localisations missing from this sheet
fields.summary: Pull sheet (git) localisations

fields.description: When I had the tree view showing all files regardless of their state, I used it to move a couple of files (context menu). After they were moved ST crashed with a report regarding the tree view being rendered.
fields.summary: Crash when moving files using tree view
Suggestion: When deleting a local branch, include option to delete upstream branch

fields.description:
From AAC: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/130079/please-make-the-commit-merged-changes-immediately-checkbox-sticky

Make this a preference setting.
fields.summary: Make "commit merged changes immediately" checkbox sticky

fields.description:
It would be very handy to be able to quickly search the working tree and/or filter the changes list like you can do already with filenames. For example if you have an issue with a method you could search for any changes involved in that method. Or if you want to tease out a commit of just its related changes.

There are a few variations of this which would all be helpful, including:
Search all the files in the working set
Search only the changes/diff in the working set (similar to git diff-index --cached -S<SEARCH STRING> HEAD) 

Originally discussed here - https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/129612/is-there-a-way-to-search-the-working-tree-changes
fields.summary: Add ability to search working tree

fields.description:
After pressing Stage File it would be very handy if the next file in working tree was selected. Right now you have to mouse down to select it then mouse back to click on Stage File again. The repeat for all 40 files :).
This is related to SRCTREE-678.
fields.summary: Select next file in working tree after clicking "Stage File" button

fields.description:
Git 1.7.7 now supports the very handy --include-untracked (or -u) option which also stashes untracked files. Which in my experience is often what I want. Would be great to have it as a checkbox option alongside the existing keep-index option.

I'll add it would be great if it remembers its last value (since we almost always use -u).
fields.summary: Support include-untracked with stash

fields.description: As you type in the box, filter the list of repos.
fields.summary: Add search/filter box in window with list of repos on hosted accounts

fields.description:
I would like to have a persistent console log that can be toggled on or off. It would be nice if it could be at the bottom of the window, maybe in a small drawer or similar effect.

Reasoning: We don't have the "Always display full console output" preference turned on because it comes up for minor actions like staging files. It's bothersome to have to dismiss this dialog for the majority of actions which are successful. It would be quicker to just glance at the output in a log window.

Problem: When pushing to a server that runs a post-receive hook, we miss the output of those scripts and can overlook an error quite easily.
fields.summary: Add persistent console log

fields.description:
I work with some glacial repos (over a slow link from US to Japan).

When the Check default blah blah background "git fetch" is happening, a lock may appear in a repo I'm trying to also look at. If I manually click Fetch in that repo, I may get a complaint about the lock file. (This is really a bug of it's own.)

I'd really like for the Bookmarks window to have a indefinite progress indicator (spinning arrows?) appear in each entry as it's being updated, perhaps a bit like how CodeWarrior used to show each file in a project being compiled.
fields.summary: need visual indication of background fetch

fields.description: I am a relatively new user of both git and Sourcetree. I stashed my changes in a project for the first time, and I found myself stumped on how to reapply the stashed changes. Google was no help, and there was no mention in the help documentation. Perhaps adding just an optional toolbar button to run 'git stash pop'? Just to help those new to the whole idea and the Sourcetree gui.
fields.summary: Might I suggest an 'unstash' or 'stash pop' button be available for the toolbar?

fields.description:
The output from git format-patch must have changed at some point, in that the first lines of the patch is now of the form:

{noformat}
From <SHA> <DATE>
From: <USER> <EMAIL>
Date: <DATE>
Subject: <COMMIT MSG>
{noformat}

The existing patch analysis which checks to see if the patch is a full commit expects the 'From: <USER>' to be the first line, but it isn't any more, even if you create the patch in SourceTree. Must have been a git change since the Apply Patch analysis was written.

We should support the new format, and keep support for the old format at the same time for people still on older versions of git.
fields.summary: Apply Patch sheet doesn't detect full git commit patches properly any more

fields.description:
The shelve feature should let me select what I want to shelve and it should allow me to shelve new files that aren't scheduled for inclusion yet.
More importantly, when addressing an existing shelve, that shelve shouldn't get overwritten with the new changes, but rather amended.

Scenario: I had one changed file and three new files. I pressed shelve and gave it a name. Suprisingly, only the changed file was shelved. Then I added the three new files and shelved again using the same name. Guess what, the shelve was overwritten and my changes to the existing file were lost. :-(
fields.summary: Shelve improvements

fields.description:
Offer the option to make a new commit immediately if there's still files in the working tree.

Via Twitter: https://twitter.com/philipmatix/status/292200504547749889
fields.summary: Multi-commit if files in working tree remaining

fields.description: Reported by Aras via STSP-359 (https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-359). This does happen. Resolution would be to keep the branches list closed if it was closed beforehand.
fields.summary: Branches tree doesn't stay closed on manual refresh

fields.description:
When your development branch is not up to date SourceTree won't let you create a new feature branch even if you select "Working Copy Revision" as your starting point.

As a result, the user has to close on three dialogs to go back and pull the development branch and then navigate back through the dialogs to try again.

Expected behavior:
1) SourceTree shouldn't care about the state of the development branch when you are creating a feature off of the working copy revision if it is not the development branch.
2) If the current branch is out of date SourceTree should just prompt the user and ask if they want to pull the latest changes. Most of the time (when there are no uncommitted changes) this will be sufficient and will save the user the hassle of having to close and reopen all the dialogs.
3) If neither of those first two solutions are available SourceTree should warn the user that the development branch is out of date as soon as they click "Start a New Feature" instead of waiting until the user has filled in the feature branch name and clicked "OK".

To Reproduce:
When the development branch is behind the remote branch
1) Checkout a non-development branch like a feature branch or hot-fix branch
2) Click Git Flow
3) Click "Start a New Feature"
4) Click "Working Copy Revision"
5) Type a feature branch name and click OK
6) Feel the pain
fields.summary: Git Flow should let you create a new feature branch on the working copy revision even when the development branch is out of date

fields.description:
When going into preferences the diff tool can be set to two options on the drop-
down. This shouldn't be possible.

Steve's comments:
"I think it occurs when you go back and forth between versions, that's when I saw it

or maybe it's when you go into the prefs window for the first time since the app loaded and the selection is NOT kaleidoscope

so if you set the merge option to something else, close the app, reload it and then check"

No reports for this yet, but it exists from 1.5.7.
fields.summary: Two selections on diff tool in preferences

fields.description:
Starting with Araxis Merge 2013.4283 (released 14 January 2013) its command line utilities are now placed inside the application bundle at "/Applications/Araxis\ Merge.app/Contents/Utilities/" so perhaps SourceTree can be updated to just look for them there? So folks would just need to install Araxis Merge and then choose it in SourceTree with no copying/linking of files.

More info:
http://www.araxis.com/merge_mac/ReleaseHistory.html
http://www.araxis.com/merge_mac/topic_installingfromweb.html

Copied from this thread - https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/72949/integration-with-araxis-merge
fields.summary: Recognize new standard location of Araxis Merge command line utilities

fields.description:
Instead of ordering tags default by their alphabetical name, instead have the preference to order them by their version. In Git's case this would have to be a commit date order, and in Mercurial we could use the revision number.

Request via Twitter: https://twitter.com/misterparker/status/291349796885786624
fields.summary: Order tags by version order as a preference

fields.description: An option to pull all remote tracking branches into local branches. This would mean the branch names would have to match otherwise there's no correlation. You can pull/push any local branch to any remote branch and vice versa so additional considerations and thoughts would need to be thought up before working on this one.
fields.summary: Pull all remote branches in Git

fields.description:
Could you change how the entries under STASHES section show up? Right now, each entry is prefixed with "On <branch name>:" with my comments after this. But, with this panel being fairly slim - you typically won't see the user comments at all.

Sure, you can expand the panel or actually click on a stashed entry to see what it is. But, it'd be a lot more useful for me anyway if you put my comments first - followed by "(<branch name)". Or, at least a tooltip when I hover over.
fields.summary: Not enough room to view label in STASHES section

fields.description:
Hi, 

First of all thanks for the best git client out there.
We are using our own git server (Gitlab) on our servers. 
Gitlab is running gitolite which have a the "info" function that can be called.
like this
ssh git@myserver info 
This will give a list of my repositories.

So my question is if it would be possible to add you own server in "Hosted Repositories" and get a list of my possible repos from there.
fields.summary: Add support for gitolite info

fields.description:
The default push branch setting seems broken in 1.5.7.
If the push branch is set to "current" under GIT preferences, when I go to push changes - the current branch isn't selected by default

(See Screenshot)

Seems to work in 1.5.6
fields.summary: GIT Push branch setting has no affect

fields.description: Support git reflog. @sourcetree mentioned on twitter :) - http://bit.ly/VV1bN6
fields.summary: Support reflog

fields.description: Requested on Twitter, the ability to select hunks when shelving changes. Shelve extensions now supports this so we can use that as our dependency.
fields.summary: Select hunks when using shelve in hg
